titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Frey Family Papers
1793-1917 (Bulk 1825-1890)
MS 235
titlestmt.author: Processed by Melissa Haley

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from frey.xml

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:48:22 -0400.

did.abstract: The Frey Family Papers primarily document multiple generations of the Frey and related Ludlow and Van Schaack families of upstate New York and elsewhere. The bulk of the collection is correspondence (16 boxes), detailing family news, health matters, and deaths; opinions on religion, politics, and the Civil War; financial, legal, and property issues and troubles; family history and genealogy.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Portions of the collection that have been microfilmed will be brought to the researcher in that format and can be made available by Interlibrary loan.

Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.) Researchers on site may print out unlimited copies from microfilm reader-printer machines at per-exposure rates. See guidelines in Reading room for details.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote, to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Frey Family Papers, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: This collection contains items for over one hundred individuals. See family trees (available at repository) for the Frey, Ludlow, and Van Schaack families for relationships, birth and death dates. These trees were compiled from a variety of sources, including the items in the collection.
Many individuals in this collection had nicknames and used them often in correspondence. The following nicknames are commonly used:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Frey Family Papers primarily document multiple generations of the Frey and related Ludlow and Van Schaack families of upstate New York and elsewhere. The bulk of the collection is correspondence (16 boxes), detailing family news, health matters, and deaths; opinions on religion, politics, and the Civil War; financial, legal, and property issues and troubles; family history and genealogy. The larger correspondence subseries include letters from Caroline Frey Winne written from army postings in the western United States during the 1870s and 1880s; letters from Samuel Ludlow Frey concerning the family farm and finances; and letters from John Frey regarding financial, legal, and property matters. Letters from Henry A. Frey detail his ongoing financial, familial, and marital difficulties. Various members of the Ludlow family are also represented, presenting their opinions on religion, politics, and current events.

This collection also contains diaries; financial, legal, and property records; genealogies; poetry; ephemera; organizational and educational material; drafts of writings; notes, memoranda, and extracts; newspapers and clippings; sketches; one photograph; and documents relating to a southern gold mine.

The Frey Family Papers support research in the histories of New York State (major locations represented include Palatine Bridge, Oswego, New York City, Albany, Kinderhook); nineteenth century family life and religion; the Civil War; and late nineteenth century western history (letters of Caroline Frey Winne). This collection also supports research in nineteenth century women's history. The letters of Caroline Ludlow Frey, Christina Cantine, Elizabeth Van Schaack Frey, Anna Ludlow, Ellen Ludlow, and Helen Ludlow, for example, discuss family and social lives, health, religion, childrearing, politics, and current events (see subseries descriptions for details). In addition, the Frey Family Papers contain a number of letters written by children. See especially Caroline Frey ["Carrie" b.1868], Helen Frey, John Frey ["Johnny" d.1858], Wallace Jones, and Charles K. Winne, Jr.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence arranged by sender. See container list for other series arrangements.
The collection is organized into the following seventeen series:

list.head: Missing Title
list.item: Series V. Land and Property Records, 1806-1873, undated
Series XII. Notes, Memoranda and Extracts, 1849-1891, undated
Series XIV. Newspapers, Clippings and Reprints, 1860-1907, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sixteen boxes. Arranged alphabetically by sender, into 102 subseries. Letters with multiple authors are filed under the first name to appear. Women, if married, are filed under their final surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern land purchase, property.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern family news, deaths, and history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey regarding family history and genealogy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning family matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding family matters, health, current events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey regarding pottery, china, stoneware.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning financial matters, family (esp. the deaths of Philip Frey and Elizabeth Frey Beardslee), family strife.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding family, local news, deaths of friend, brother, and child, medical and health matters, child rearing and weaning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern family news, books read, travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding finances, wool.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern family matters, especially condolence letters for the deaths of Henry Van Schaack Frey, Henry I. Frey, Elizabeth Frey Beardslee, and Phebe Ludlow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding property, finances, family deaths.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters Johnny Frey and Samuel Ludlow Frey concerning school, penmanship, holidays, alcohol, farm life, weather, and politics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Travel letters from Italy, Scotland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Henry A. Frey regarding gold mining ventures in the Carolinas, especially at King's Mountain, N.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Caroline Ludlow Frey regarding courtship, friendship, local gossip, religion, social news, local and family deaths.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from Conkling family members regarding family matters, politics. Includes:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Henry F. Cox, including two lengthy letters from abroad (Syria and Egypt, 1856, 1857) that describe his travels throughout the Mid East and down the Nile River. There are also letters from Margaret and Seraphine Cox.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, mostly to John Frey, concerning the Davies family, romantic advice, religion, Frey's financial matters, the Civil War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey regarding Herkimer, Dygert and Deuel family genealogies, New York State history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning the family farm, weather, family news, health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to various family members dealing with family news, his work in the insurance industry, politics (particularly the election of 1860 and his enthusiasm over Lincoln), New York State excursions, the Civil War (Frey joined a Zouaves regiment, the 110th NYSV, in the Union Army summer of 1862), job prospects after the war, weather.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to her various family members, children and husband concerning family matters, deaths, religion, health and ailments, advice to children, sewing.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Frey, Caroline Ludlow (to Caroline Frey Winne)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly childhood letters to her grandfather concerning activities on the farm. Also letters from Wells College, Aurora, NY, describing her studies there.

did.unittitle: Subseries 30. Frey, Elizabeth Van Schaack, 1824-1833, undated ["Betsey"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters (most to her son John) offering advice, and detailing family news, her religious convictions, local gossip, and the deaths of three of her children.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Frey, Elizabeth Van Schaack

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters (most from Springfield, OH) regarding family news and deaths (particularly his father, wife, and children), family history, politics (esp. the 1876 election and Conkling), Custer, and other contemporary events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Childhood letters about the farm, family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning family news, her children's activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from Darien, WI, promoting Wisconsin and detailing local life, particularly farming, the railroad. Also discusses the family, health, weather, disease and death, finances, religion, politics (particularly the Republican Party and Roscoe Conkling), the impending secession, and the Civil War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to family members (most from Cleveland, Chicago, and Indiana) regarding family matters, his involvement in coal dealing, various entrepreneurial schemes, continual financial troubles, his attempts to enlist in the Union army, involvement in the Civil War, and in a gold mining venture at King's Mountain, NC. Frey also discusses familial discord, his debts to family members, accusations of impropriety, the dissolution of his marriage, and his emotional troubles. There is a gap in the letters from 1864 to 1866.

did.unittitle: Subseries 36. Frey, Henry A. [probably son of Augustus B. Frey], 1912

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One letter about the birth of his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters (most to son John) regarding family and farm news, health, land sales, local news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters describing his school and fellow students, travels in New York State, future plans.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Frey, Henry Van Schaack

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about family history, the death of his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early letters detail his schooling, legal studies, his religious conversion at the age of twenty, and his 1828 marriage to Caroline Ludlow. In late1829, Frey accompanied his brother Henry to St. Augustine, FL, where the latter hoped to find respite from his lung ailment. Letters from Florida describe local population, food, Henry's health and subsequent death in early 1830. Frey's letters from 1830 to 1865 concern his finances, family, legal matters, property and land sales, the farm and planting, limestone and willow trees, family strife with the Beardslees, and the Civil War. There is a gap in the letters from 1845 to 1850, and from 1865 to 1872. After 1872, and a move to Hoboken, N.J., the letters concern the death of his wife (1873), his job at the Custom House, New York City, grandchildren, family news and health. There is also a gap from 1874 to 1877.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about farm activities, weather.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern the dissolution of her marriage to Henry A. Frey, and finances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One letter to his mother concerning the family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One letter to his son about family matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most letters are written from Decatur, AL, and detail family matters and history; opinions on the Civil War, Southern and national politics; local customs, gardening, weather, farming, keeping chickens, and cotton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early letters written from school in Poughkeepsie detail his studies, local events, family news (esp. Ludlow family), weddings and social events, dental procedures, and weather. Later letters from Palatine Bridge discuss the family's financial troubles, deaths, land sales, the Civil War, farming and winemaking, and health. There is a gap in the letters from 1865 to 1872. After 1872, his letters continue to describe finances and debt, farming, health, and local news. Also under discussion are his mother's death in 1873, other deaths, politics, the railroad, Henry A. Frey's continual financial troubles, digging for Indian relics, articles written and submitted for publication, and family news. There is another gap in the letters from 1883 to 1895. Later letters concern family and local history, and a dispute with the New York Central & Hudson River Co. over a fence and drainage on Frey property.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from Racine, WI, regarding family news and history, health, deaths, women's rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning New York State history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about Seattle, social events, travel plans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey requesting that he speak before the Montgomery County Historical Society on Sir William Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey regarding New York State history, and Frey's writings including "The Story of Our River" and "The Mohawks."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey from Leavenworth, KS about family history and news, travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, presumably to John Frey, containing family and local news, deaths, politics, health, financial matters, the death of Hees' wife, and Frey's legal troubles with George A. Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from Racine, WI concerning family health, news, deaths.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to John Frey regarding local news, finances, property sales, limestone, farming, politics, and the impending Civil War. Johnson also discusses his son Alonzo's financial dealings with Frey and his whereabouts in California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Samuel Ludlow Frey of holiday greetings, family news, school and college, and travels. Includes:
Barbara (1911-1912), Helen [probably Helen Jones Jr.] (1899, 1910), Helen [probably Helen Jones Sr.] (1910-1911),Wallace (1899, 1910-1913, undated).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to Henry I. Frey regarding finances, land sales.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters discussing local news, deaths (particularly of Caroline Ludlow Frey), health and illness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning family news, illnesses, and deaths (especially the death of her mother Phebe Ludlow); also her husband Rev. L.E. Lathrop's leaving his ministerial post.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes: Henry (1841), J.M. (1875), Leonard (1832); 1 item each.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding family news, finances, health and illnesses, the death of her mother (1877), and the family vault. Some letters (1873-1875) are written from Savannah and Charlestown, detailing her work as a teacher of African-American children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters written from Oswego, NY, most to John Frey, concerning the family, health, her father, Samuel Baldwin Ludlow, his illness and death (1882); religion and the local church, women and religion, the Beecher scandal; Oswego news, deaths, politics, weather.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, most to Samuel Ludlow Frey, detailing family news, school life, opinions on religion, his religious conversion, lecturing stints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about family news, reflections on her father, Rev. Henry Gilbert Ludlow; some items written from the Hampton Institute, Va., but do not go into great detail about school life; others written from St. Augustine, FL.

did.unittitle: Subseries 70. Ludlow, Henry Gilbert, Rev., 1824-1865, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning the state of religion in New York City, New Haven, Poughkeepsie, religious instruction, Catholicism, cholera (1832), John Frey's financial troubles, illness and family deaths, death of his mother, Phebe Ludlow (1840), births, his children, love letters to his second wife Maria Tappen (1851).

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Ludlow, Rev. Henry Gilbert
Letters sent: Ludlow, Rev. Henry Gilbert
Letters sent: Ludlow, Rev. Henry Gilbert

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Love letters to Rev. Henry Gilbert Ludlow, also discussing family and New York City news, FitzHugh Ludlow's future, and wedding plans.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Ludlow, Maria Beekman Tappen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, most written from Philadelphia, concerning family and local news, religious revivals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early letters (through 1831) are written from Philadelphia; from 1836 on, written from Oswego, NY. They discuss family news and troubles, health problems (particularly his eyes), local politics, businesses, including insurance, gas and railroad, politics, Ulysses S. Grant, Roscoe Conkling, racial issues (c1875), the Beecher scandal, his daughter Ellen, the last illness and death of his wife, Nancy Douglas Ludlow (1877), physical ailments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes: Ambrose (1828, 1841; 2 items), [Elizabeth (prob., b.1830)] (1855-1856, undated; 5 items), Harry (1899; 1 item), Phebe (undated; 1 item), Rosalie (1860; 1 item), Samuel Baldwin, Jr. ["Baldwin"] (1856-1857; 4 items).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to John Frey, most written from California, regarding the prospects for California, Frey's financial and legal dispute with Alonzo Johnson and the latter's whereabouts, local news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters discussing family news, deaths of various family members.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Pruyn, Margaret Van Schaack

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about the Frey family farm, cows, planting, and finances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about family news and deaths.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, most to John Frey, concerning land sales, financial matters with Frey, family news and deaths.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters about family news and deaths, visits, and Henry Van Schaack Frey's grave in St. Augustine.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Van Schaack, Henry C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding land, finances, family news, and the death of Henry Van Schaack Frey.

did.unittitle: Subseries 90. Van Schaack, Peter Jr., 1820, 1832, 1851, 1862, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concerning land, his father's health, family news and health.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Van Schaack, Peter Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters regarding family news, finances, the deaths of his mother, wife, and Caroline Ludlow Frey, romantic advice to John Frey.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Van Schaack, Peter C.
Subseries 92. Van Schaack family, others, 1848-1900, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes: Anna (1877; 2 items), Asa (1848; 1 item), Catherine (1877; 2 items), Christina (1 item), David (1900; 2 items), Dorcas (undated; 1 item), John Jay [probably son of David] (1863-1877; 4 items), Peter [son of Henry C.] (1868, 1899; 5 items).

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Van Schaack family, others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters to John Frey regarding Frey's finances, national politics, land sales, the Wagner family, the Civil War, Frey's legal matters, foreclosure.

did.unittitle: Subseries 95. Winne, Caroline Frey Giddings, 1851-1899, undated ["Carrie," "Sis"]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

p.emph: On microfilm: Dec. 1874-May 1880, Misc. Reel #61. July 1883-July 1887, Misc. Reel #19.

scopecontent.p: Letters written from Nebraska (1874-1878) were published in Nebraska History, Spring 1981, pp. 1-46.
Caroline E. Frey married Col. Grotius R. Giddings in 1862; he died in 1867. She married army surgeon Dr. Charles K. Winne in 1874.
Chronology of postings:

chronitem.event: Fort Trumbull, CT; New Orleans, LA; Oswego, NY; Palatine Bridge, NY

scopecontent.p: Early letters detail family news and her first husband's illnesses, and her mother's death (1873). Letters from Nebraska (12/1874-1/1878), describe local Native Americans, a meeting with Sitting Bull (2/13/1875), her husband's family troubles, her pregnancy and difficult childbirth (1875), violent incidents in the frontier town, health and small pox, complaints about army life and servants, the death of Crazy Horse (letter 9/9/1877), the birth of Charles K. Winne Jr. (9/30/1877), her husband's position in the army and his opportunities for reappointment. Letters from 1878 through mid-1883 discuss the baby, the journey to Wyoming, and her health; and contain descriptions of Wyoming, including a Shoshone Sundance (5/25/1879). An eighteen-page letter of 6/17/1883 and postcards detail her transcontinental railroad journey to California. Letters from California contain family news; reports of her son's education; reactions to the deaths of Henry A. Frey and her father, John Frey; descriptions of the weather, local life, numerous post transfers; opinions on the Chinese and Chinese servants (see especially letters of 1/3/1886, 4/19/[1887], 10/9/1887).

Note: a number of Caroline Frey Winne's undated letters have been tentatively dated, in pencil and in brackets, by a previous processor. The accuracy of these dates has not been verified, and these letters have been moved into the undated folders at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most letters concern Caroline Frey Winne's pregnancy in 1875 and her poor condition following childbirth (baby was stillborn or died soon after). Later letters discuss the birth of Charles K. Winne, Jr. and family matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly childhood letters about pets, excursions, family, botany. Later letters discuss family visits.

did.unittitle: Letters sent: Winne, Charles K., Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters concern John Frey's finances, family matters (both Frey and Wynkoop), mortgages, fishing, and the varnish business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alienated and blank envelopes; loose stamps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief entries in pocket diaries concerning family matters, weather, social events, playing cricket, politics, finances, fishing, botany, Indian relic hunting, and articles written. Most entries simply detail daily farm activities such as plowing and planting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Spiritual diaries. Many are unbound, loose sheets. Only the first of these diaries is signed by Caroline Ludlow [Frey], the rest are assumed to be hers. Entries are reflections on religion and particular sermons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pocket diary probably belonging to Helen Ludlow. Entries detail daily household and social activities, family news, her emotional state, reading, cooking, trips to Niagara and Boston, her father's sermons, and what appears to be an aborted courtship. Notes in the back of the volume include a list of daily chores, poetry, and finances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John Frey's brief travel diary of his excursion to St. Augustine, FL with his ailing brother Henry.

did.unittitle: Diary: [John Frey], travels to St. Augustine, FL

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes an unidentified author's weather diary for Jan., 1829, an unidentified author's brief travel diary for a trip to Virginia in 1892, and a mostly blank pocket diary of an unidentified author.

did.unittitle: Diary: unidentified, travel diary to Va.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains Frey family account books, bills, loose accounts, bonds, promissory notes, receipts, printed reports, and calculations. Sorted by last date on item. Printed reports include insurance company statements and annual reports for the town of Palatine, NY. Account books include two 1863 volumes (possibly belonging to Henry A. Frey) detailing items (alcohol, food, cigars) sold to Union troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes indentures, bonds, court papers (including copies of opinions), notes, drafts of wills, agreements, estate inventories and papers, notices, articles of agreement. Many of the items concern John Frey's financial and legal troubles, especially the undated material.

did.unittitle: Series V. Land and Property Records, 1806-1873, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes surveys, memorandum, records of patent lots, articles of agreement, indentures, and sales of Frey family land. Also one folder of house plans.

did.unittitle: Land and property records: house plans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes family trees for the Van Schaack, Ludlow, and Herkimer families, as well as a North family register, and notes on the Herkimer, Yates, and Roach families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies of published poems, as well as poetry that is most likely original, including FitzHugh Ludlow's "Epistle from a brave of the Ludlow Tribe to a distinguished Mohawk," written for his cousin, Samuel Ludlow Frey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes invitations, announcements, and programs for various events including balls, festivals, weddings, meetings, concerts, tournaments, and historical commemorations (including the 1876 centennial and an anniversary celebration of the Emancipation Proclamation at Hampton Institute); an announcement for the sale of the Frey family farm; death notices; advertisements for barbed wire fences, farm machinery, health remedies, wine making paraphernalia; circulars for beehives and globes; direct mail from the Republican State Committee; calling cards; catalogs for an antique auction with notes; and a railroad timetable for the Chicago, Burlington, and Quincy Railroad.

did.unittitle: Ephemera: announcement, sale of Frey farm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material relating to the meetings of various organizations, including the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Oneida Historical Society, the Scotch-Irish Society of America, and the Daughters of the American Revolution. Also included is the handwritten, undated "Eighth Annual Report of the Female Praying Society."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains report cards, an achievement certificate for Frey children, and two school notebooks.

did.unittitle: Notebook: unidentified [possibly Elizabeth Frey], "Deffinitions," geographical terms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Drafts for Samuel Ludlow Frey's, The Story of Our River and The Colonel and the Major. Also a draft of an article probably written by Frey, "Were They Mound Builders," and a brief, early essay of his (possibly for school) entitled "Old, times." Drafts of writings in the hand of John Frey discuss politics, slavery, homeopathy, and insurance. This series also includes what appear to be drafts of addresses, in the hand of John Frey. Topics include temperance, farming and agriculture, slavery, religion, politics, and education. As one document names Frey as recorder for an unnamed society, these addresses are not necessarily his own work. In addition, three drafts of works by unidentified authors are located in this series.

did.unittitle: Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 1-2
Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 3-4
Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 5-6
Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 7-8
Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 9-10
Drafts: SLF, The Colonel and the Major, Ch. 11
Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 1-3
Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 4-5
Drafts: SLF, The Story of Our River, Ch. 8-9
Series XII. Notes, Memoranda and Extracts, 1849-1891, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many of the loose sheets are unidentified. They include extracts from plays, speeches, newspapers; quotations; axioms; religious notes; fragments of writings on various topics; lists; exercises. Notes attributed to Samuel Ludlow Frey have been previously separated. They consist of notes about history and books; quotations; and extracts.

Bound notebooks include Samuel Ludlow Frey's "Flora of Palatine"; an unidentified volume containing "Speech of Hon. Hen. Wilson," and religious reflections and notes; an unidentified volume containing notes on the history of upstate New York; Mary Tank's notebook of pressed flowers; and a blank notebook belonging to John Frey.

did.unittitle: Notebook: Samuel Ludlow Frey, "Flora of Palatine"
Notebook: unidentified, "Speech of Hon. Hen. Wilson," religious reflections and notes
Notebook: unidentified, historical notes of upstate New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes documents relating to Henry A. Frey's involvement in a gold mining venture in South Carolina, including gold bullion deposit receipts, copies of indentures, articles of agreement, leases, and surveys.

did.unittitle: Series XIV. Newspapers, Clippings and Reprints, 1860-1907, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains newspapers and clippings, mostly from upstate New York publications, many of which contain articles by Samuel Ludlow Frey. Also reprints of articles, most from the Utica Morning Herald, regarding Samuel Ludlow Frey, his interests, and the Oneida Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sketches of various unlabeled plants and flowers, a profile of a child, and a sketch presumably by Carrie Frey Winne, of the San Francisco Bay area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One cased daguerreotype portrait of three unidentified men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Blank pieces of paper, blank forms, and one flattened wax seal of an unidentified building.
